item.title: Tam To’s Easy No-Roll Egg Rolls
item.description: Egg rolls can be time-consuming and tedious to make, but this hack makes them a lot easier. Vietnamese egg rolls are generously filled, and rolling them is a lot harder than it looks. Sometimes, you can’t tell when the filling is fully cooked, either. With this hack, there’s no need to create rolls, and the air fryer ensures they turn out crispy and delicious. —Tam To, Los Angeles, California

item.title: THE EVOLUTION OF THE IRISH PUB MENU: FROM STEW TO SUSH
item.description:
The Irish pub has long been a cornerstone of community life, offering warmth, hospitality, and a hearty meal to go with a pint. For generations, the menu was simple and comforting—think steaming bowls of Irish stew, plates of coddle, or a classic shepherd’s pie. These dishes reflected Ireland’s farming and fishing traditions, with ingredients drawn directly from the land and sea. Table of Contents Introduction: More than a Pint and a Stew The Traditional Pub Menu Global Influences Begin The Gastro Pub Movement The Modern Pub Menu and Beyond More than a Pint and a Stew But the Irish pub has never been frozen in time. Over the decades, pub menus have expanded, diversified, and embraced global flavors. From Italian pasta in the 1980s to the rise of gourmet burgers in the 1990s and sushi rolls appearing in today’s gastropubs, the story of the pub menu is also the story of a changing Ireland. As tastes evolved, so too did the food that accompanied a pint of Guinness or a glass of whiskey. The Traditional Pub Menu For much of the 19th and 20th centuries, the Irish pub menu was rooted in hearty, home-style dishes designed to nourish working people. These meals were inexpensive, filling, and made from ingredients that were readily available in rural Ireland. In many ways, they reflected the nation’s agricultural and fishing heritage. Among the classics was the Irish stew, often made with mutton or lamb, potatoes, onions, and carrots. This dish symbolized comfort and thrift, stretching simple ingredients into a communal meal. Dublin coddle, another staple, combined sausages, rashers, onions, and potatoes in a slow-cooked broth, making use of leftovers in a satisfying way. Seafood also played an important role, especially in coastal pubs. Seafood chowder brimming with fresh fish, mussels, and cream became a beloved dish, paired with slices of brown soda bread for dipping. In the west, boxty—a potato pancake fried on a griddle—was another traditional offering, celebrating Ireland’s most important crop. These dishes were not just about flavor; they were about sustenance. A pub meal needed to warm the body, fill the stomach, and complement a pint of stout or ale. The atmosphere was simple and familiar, with food served in large portions to match the generosity of Irish hospitality. For many decades, these traditional meals dominated pub menus across Ireland. Yet by the late 20th century, global influences began to find their way onto the table, slowly reshaping what it meant to dine in an Irish pub. Global Influences Begin By the 1980s and 1990s, Ireland was changing rapidly, and so too were its pubs. The arrival of new ingredients, increased tourism, and the influence of Irish emigrants returning home with fresh ideas meant that the pub menu could no longer remain limited to stew and soda bread. Instead, it began to expand, reflecting Ireland’s growing openness to the world. One of the first signs of this shift was the introduction of Italian-inspired dishes such as lasagna, spaghetti bolognese, and garlic bread. These meals became staples in many pubs, appealing both to locals looking for variety and tourists seeking familiar flavors. At the same time, American-style burgers and fries started appearing, quickly becoming pub favorites and remaining popular to this day. Another international influence came from closer to home: Britain’s love of Indian curries. Curry chips, a simple but addictive combination of crispy fries topped with curry sauce, spread across Irish pubs and fast-food counters, becoming a late-night essential. This era was also when pubs began to experiment with Tex-Mex dishes like nachos, chili con carne, and fajitas, widening their appeal to younger, more adventurous eaters. Global flavors were no longer confined to city centers—rural pubs, too, were updating their menus. While some traditionalists resisted these changes, for many Irish pub-goers, the blending of global dishes with old favorites was a welcome evolution. By the time the Celtic Tiger economy of the 1990s and early 2000s boomed, Ireland’s pubs had become far more cosmopolitan, setting the stage for the rise of the gastropub. The Gastro Pub Movement As Ireland entered the 2000s, the rise of the gastropub transformed the way people thought about pub dining. No longer was the pub simply a place for hearty, filling food—it became a space where chefs could showcase creativity, celebrate local ingredients, and elevate traditional dishes to new culinary heights. The gastropub movement emphasized seasonality and provenance. Menus highlighted local farms, dairies, and fisheries, reflecting a growing appreciation for food sustainability. Classic dishes such as Irish stew and fish and chips were reimagined with gourmet twists, often paired with artisan sauces or craft beer reductions. At the same time, artisan cheeses, charcuterie boards, and wild game made their way onto menus. Pub-goers could enjoy rabbit terrine, venison burgers, or farmhouse cheeses served with chutneys—items that would have been unthinkable on a pub menu a generation earlier. The gastropub also aligned perfectly with the craft beer boom. Pubs began offering curated beer pairings alongside their dishes, showcasing how locally brewed stouts, ales, and IPAs could complement everything from shellfish to slow-cooked meats. Whiskey tastings, too, became part of the dining experience. This shift didn’t just attract food lovers—it elevated the reputation of Irish pubs internationally. Suddenly, pubs weren’t only watering holes but destinations for fine dining, drawing tourists eager to experience Irish hospitality with a gourmet twist. By blending tradition with innovation, the gastropub marked a turning point. And yet, the evolution of the Irish pub menu didn’t stop there. Today, global flavors have become an everyday part of pub dining, with some offerings that would have once seemed unimaginable. The Modern Pub Menu and Beyond Today, walking into an Irish pub means encountering a menu that reflects both tradition and global influence. The staples remain—Irish stew, coddle, chowder, and shepherd’s pie—but they now share the stage with dishes from every corner of the world. It is no longer unusual to find sushi platters, tapas boards, or vegan curries alongside a pint of Guinness. Pub

The post THE EVOLUTION OF THE IRISH PUB MENU: FROM STEW TO SUSH appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: PRATIE OATEN
item.description:
Pratie Oaten – Traditional Irish Potato Oat Griddle Bread Description: Pratie Oaten is a traditional Irish sweet griddle bread made from mashed potatoes and oatmeal. Simple, hearty, and lightly sweetened, it was once a common farmhouse treat enjoyed hot off the griddle with butter, honey, or jam. Preparation Time: 15 minutesCooking Time: 15 minutesServing Size: Serves 6 Ingredients 250g (1 cup) mashed potatoes, cooled 150g (1 ½ cups) medium oatmeal (rolled oats, coarsely ground) 2 tbsp sugar ½ tsp baking soda Pinch of salt 50g (3 tbsp) butter, melted 50–75ml (3–5 tbsp) buttermilk (enough to bring dough together) Instructions Step 1 – Prepare the Dough In a large bowl, mix the mashed potatoes with oatmeal, sugar, baking soda, and salt. Stir in the melted butter, then gradually add buttermilk until you have a soft, workable dough. Step 2 – Shape the Bread Turn the dough onto a floured surface. Pat into a round about 1 cm (½ inch) thick. Cut into four triangles (farls). Step 3 – Cook on the Griddle Heat a lightly greased griddle or heavy frying pan over medium heat. Cook the farls for 4–5 minutes on each side until golden brown and cooked through. Step 4 – Serve Enjoy warm with butter, honey, or jam for a truly authentic Irish farmhouse taste.

The post PRATIE OATEN appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: Elise Jesse’s Game-Day Cheese Ball
item.description: Bring serious game-day energy to your table with this football-shaped cheese ball. It’s a bold, creamy, bacon-loaded crowd-pleaser made with softened cream cheese, sharp cheddar, ranch and taco seasoning. Shape it into a football, then coat it with crispy bacon for the finishing touch. Serve with crackers, pretzels or tortilla chips, and watch it disappear before halftime. —Elise Jesse, Cincinnati, Ohio

item.title: TASTES OF THE WILD ATLANTIC WAY: A CULINARY ROAD TRIP
item.description:
Stretching over 2,500 km along Ireland’s rugged western coastline, the Wild Atlantic Way is one of the world’s longest defined coastal touring routes. Famous for its breathtaking landscapes, windswept cliffs, and charming villages, this journey is also a feast for the senses. From fresh Atlantic seafood to farmhouse cheeses, traditional breads, and locally crafted drinks, the Wild Atlantic Way offers a culinary experience as unforgettable as its scenery. Table of Contents Introduction: The Wild Atlantic Way as Ireland’s Culinary Highway Donegal to Sligo – From Seaweed Shores to Hearty Lamb Mayo to Galway – Oysters, Festivals, and Farmhouse Traditions Clare to Kerry – Coastal Comforts and Rustic Flavors Cork – Ireland’s Foodie Capital at the Journey’s End The Wild Atlantic Way as Ireland’s Culinary Highway The Wild Atlantic Way is more than a scenic road trip—it’s a living pantry of Ireland’s finest ingredients and food traditions. Every region along the route boasts its own specialties, from the seaweed-rich diets of Donegal, to Galway’s famous oysters, Kerry’s world-class lamb, and Cork’s bustling food markets. Travelers who follow this path can savor not just the flavors of Ireland, but the history, heritage, and hospitality behind each dish. Donegal to Sligo – From Seaweed Shores to Hearty Lamb The northern gateway to the Wild Atlantic Way begins in County Donegal, where untamed coastlines and traditional foodways still shape daily life. Here, the Atlantic Ocean provides an abundance of shellfish, while seaweed—long a staple in local diets—remains a prized ingredient. Known as Ireland’s “sea vegetable,” seaweed is foraged fresh from the shore and used in soups, breads, and even sweet treats like dulse paired with caramel. Seafood lovers will find Donegal irresistible, with fresh lobster, mussels, and crab available in coastal villages. Traditional dishes such as coddle of fish and smoked mackerel highlight the strong seafaring heritage of this region. For something more unusual, visitors can sample dulse, a dried seaweed snack that has sustained coastal communities for generations. Traveling south into Sligo, the landscape shifts to rolling hills and fertile farmland. This is prime sheep country, where Sligo lamb is renowned for its tender, flavorful meat thanks to the salt-rich grasses the animals graze on near the coast. Pair it with locally grown root vegetables, and you have a meal that reflects the rugged but generous land. Sligo is also becoming a hub for artisan food producers. From hand-crafted cheeses to organic vegetables and sourdough bread, the county’s small-scale farmers and food innovators are breathing new life into traditional Irish flavors. Farmers’ markets in Sligo town are perfect for sampling these goods, offering everything from wildflower honey to locally roasted coffee. In this stretch of the Wild Atlantic Way, food reflects both the sea and the land—simple, honest, and deeply tied to place. Whether you’re slurping fresh mussels in Donegal or savoring a roast of Sligo lamb, you’re tasting the heart of Ireland’s northwest. Mayo to Galway – Oysters, Festivals, and Farmhouse Traditions Heading south along the Wild Atlantic Way, County Mayo greets travelers with a rugged coastline dotted with fishing villages. Here, food traditions are as enduring as the landscapes themselves. Freshly caught Atlantic salmon, wild mussels, and cockles are celebrated in local pubs and restaurants. For generations, families in Mayo have also relied on the humble potato, often paired with fresh fish or turned into hearty dishes like pratie oaten—a sweet griddle bread of mashed potatoes and oats. As the road winds into Galway, food culture takes on a festive atmosphere. The city is famous for the Galway International Oyster and Seafood Festival, held every September, which draws visitors from across the globe to sample the finest oysters harvested from Galway Bay. These oysters, known for their briny sweetness, are considered among the best in the world and are often enjoyed with a splash of lemon or paired with a pint of Guinness. Galway’s food scene extends well beyond oysters. The county is home to a thriving network of farmhouse cheese makers, craft brewers, and small-scale distillers. Visitors can sample everything from creamy goat cheese to artisan chocolates and innovative gins infused with local botanicals. Traditional music spills out from pubs, where hearty bowls of seafood chowder and freshly baked brown bread keep both locals and visitors well-fed. Farmhouse traditions are deeply rooted here, too. Many rural families still bake soda bread daily, churn butter, and tend to small herds of cattle or sheep. This connection to the land gives Galway’s food its unmistakable authenticity—a reminder that the Wild Atlantic Way is as much about community and heritage as it is about taste. From Mayo’s rustic simplicity to Galway’s vibrant celebrations, this stretch of the journey captures the essence of western Ireland: fresh, local, and full of life. Clare to Kerry – Coastal Comforts and Rustic Flavors From the windswept Cliffs of Moher in County Clare to the rolling green hills of Kerry, this stretch of the Wild Atlantic Way offers some of the most iconic scenery in Ireland—and some of the most comforting foods. In Clare, traditional flavors thrive in homely kitchens and coastal restaurants. A must-try is the county’s famous seafood chowder, brimming with Atlantic fish, mussels, and creamy broth, often served with freshly baked brown soda bread. Clare is also known for its farmhouse butter and local cheeses, made from milk produced by cows that graze on the lush pastures of the Burren. Farmers’ markets in Ennis and nearby towns showcase everything from artisan jams to handmade chocolates, making it a perfect stop for foodies eager to explore regional specialties. Continuing south into Kerry, visitors discover a county renowned for its world-class Kerry lamb. The unique flavor of this meat comes from sheep grazing on salt-kissed grasslands near the coast. Whether enjoyed as a roast or in a traditional Irish stew, Kerry lamb is celebrated as one of Ireland’s finest meats. Local seafood is equally exceptional, with Dingle’s bustling harbor offering fresh hake, crab, and lobster straight from the Atlantic. Kerry is also home to time-honored baking

The post TASTES OF THE WILD ATLANTIC WAY: A CULINARY ROAD TRIP appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: OATEN SHORTCAKES WITH BERRY COMPOTE
item.description:
Description: Oaten Shortcakes are a rustic Irish twist on the classic scone, made with wholesome oats for extra texture and flavor. Paired with a fresh berry compote, they make a delightful tea-time treat or dessert that celebrates simple, hearty baking. Preparation Time: 20 minutes Cooking Time: 20 minutes Serving Size: Serves 6 Ingredients For the Oaten Shortcakes 200g (1 ½ cups) plain flour 100g (1 cup) rolled oats 2 tbsp sugar 2 tsp baking powder ½ tsp salt 75g (5 tbsp) cold butter, cubed 150ml (⅔ cup) buttermilk 1 egg, beaten (for glaze) For the Berry Compote 300g (2 cups) mixed berries (fresh or frozen) 2 tbsp sugar (adjust to taste) 1 tsp lemon juice Instructions Step 1 – Make the Compote In a saucepan, combine the berries, sugar, and lemon juice. Simmer gently for 8–10 minutes until the berries soften and the mixture thickens slightly. Set aside to cool. Step 2 – Prepare the Shortcake Dough Preheat oven to 200°C (400°F). In a large bowl, mix flour, oats, sugar, baking powder, and salt. Rub in the butter until the mixture resembles coarse breadcrumbs. Stir in the buttermilk to form a soft dough. Step 3 – Shape and Bake Turn the dough onto a floured surface and gently pat to about 2cm (¾ inch) thick. Cut into rounds with a cutter. Place on a lined baking tray, brush tops with beaten egg, and bake for 15–18 minutes until golden brown. Step 4 – Serve Split the shortcakes while warm, spoon over berry compote, and serve with cream or yogurt if desired.

The post OATEN SHORTCAKES WITH BERRY COMPOTE appeared first on Irish Food Hub.

item.title: I Tried Beyoncé’s Honey Bee Cocktail and I’ll Be Shaking It All Season Long

It's rich and moist, infused with warm bourbon and sweet maple syrup and sprinkled with melty pockets of chocolate toffee that caramelize as it bakes. Every bite is a perfect storm of cozy, boozy and indulgent, making it just as welcome at a brunch table as it is for a late-night treat. —Elise Jesse, Cincinnati, Ohio

item.title: Alex Bala’s Maple Brown Butter Pound Cake
item.description: This maple brown butter pound cake is rich, nutty and perfectly moist. The maple adds cozy sweetness, and a drizzle of cream cheese frosting makes every bite even better than the first! It's a simple yet impressive cake for any occasion. —Alex Bala, Longmont, Colorado

item.title: Tyler Smith’s Barbecue Smash Tacos
item.description: Turn yesterday’s backyard barbecue into something totally new! We’re transforming leftovers into barbecue smashed tacos using smoky grilled flavors you already love. By crisping up the meat for that irresistible crunch and topping it with a zesty, spicy coleslaw, you'll create a fresh, flavorful twist on a classic taco. It’s the perfect way to repurpose good eats into an easy, exciting weeknight meal. —Tyler Smith, Virginia Beach, Virginia

item.title: Elise Jesse’s White Chicken Chili Nachos
item.description: Get ready to meet your new game-day obsession! These white chicken chili nachos are fully loaded and capture everything you love about the cozy, slow-simmered flavor of white chicken chili, but in a convenient nacho form. The chili is piled high on crispy tortilla chips, smothered in melty cheese and finished with all the fixings: fresh jalapenos, sour cream and cilantro. It's comfort food with a crunch—bold, messy and made to share. —Elise Jesse, Cincinnati, Ohio
